summary: for the send a ship meme: throbb and jongritte cause i know you ship them!!! also not sure if u ship sansaery and gendrya but...
question: for the send a ship meme: throbb and jongritte cause i know you ship them!!! also not sure if u ship sansaery and gendrya but those two as well if you're a fan! <3
answer:
Hey! Thank you and sorry, I realised how late it was last night and needed to get up this morning… anyways! I’m going to do Jongritte here <333

  • who hogs the duvet - they both battle over it throughout the night and compromise by wrapping themselves around each other.
  • who texts/rings to check how their day is going - Jon will text and Ygritte will return with a call.
  • who’s the most creative when it comes to gifts - They both have the same tactics when it comes to gifts - they favour experiences. For Jon this means romantic gestures, Ygrittes have the tendency to stray into more racy territory.
  • who gets up first in the morning - They are both early rises
  • who suggests new things in bed - Ygritte normally does so when Jon does she loves it and throws herself into it
  • who cries at movies - Ygritte does, she can become very passionate about these things, her heart goes into them.
  • who gives unprompted massages - Well, Jon is usually angling for one. He does the whole ‘ugh, my back’.
  • who fusses over the other when they’re sick - Jon fuses over Ygritte because she is rarely ill and refuses to take it easy.
  • who gets jealous easiest - Jon gets jealous most because Ygritte has a plethora of exes.
  • who has the most embarrassing taste in music - Jon, mostly because he refuses to listen to anything that isn’t a very specific genre from his teenage years.
  • who takes the longest to get ready - Jon, as when he starts to get ready Ygritte will often take advantage of his state of undress
  • who is the most tidy and organised - both are tidy and organised but Jon is more particular.
  • who gets most excited about the holidays - Ygritte, she enjoys now having the Stark’s enthusiasm in her life.
  • who is the big spoon/little spoon - they sleep face to face (heathens)
  • who gets most competitive when playing games and/or sports - Ygritte, Jon tries to make sure they are on the same team when possible and then sits back and watches 
  • who starts the most arguments - Jon, but they can both get heated. The make up sex is always excellent though. 
  • who suggests that they buy a pet - Neither, Jon comes to the relationship with Ghost
  • what couple traditions they have - Visiting hot springs (these two eh?)
  • what tv shows they watch together - pretty much everything
  • what other couple they hang out with - Sam and Gilly, and Alys and Sigorn
  • how they spend time together as a couple - They enjoy things like climbing and hiking together
  • who made the first move - Ygritte in a very teasing way
  • who brings flowers home - Jon brings Ygritte flowers that remind her of home (My headcanon in modern au is Ygritte as Scottish so he goes to fancy florists with thistles. She likes a lot of interesting and textured foliage).
  • who is the best cook - Ygritte, and she is particularly keen of a bit of a kick in her food.

summary: Seriously, this is such a ‘married’ King and Queen moment. He just waltzes up like he has a right to know where and what she’s...
caption: Seriously, this is such a ‘married’ King and Queen moment. He just waltzes up like he has a right to know where and what she’s doing. He aint happy and she throws it back at him pointing out his own dealings of the same nature. They met like what? 3 weeks ago? The mutual respect is there already. She didn’t have to tell him a thing, yet she does. She does the same thing in the Dragonpit. “So what now?” And she tells him exactly what’s running through her head. The uncertainty and fear, all of it because there is unwavering trust and understanding there. They were showing signs of what a great rapport they were bound to have from the start. “We both want to help people. We can only help them from a position of strength. Sometime’s strength is terrible.” Kindred souls much?

summary: George RR Martin’s last “Game of Thrones” Script had “Arya Stark” as the Key to the North.“Martin has Roose Bolton tell his...
caption:
George RR Martin’s last “Game of Thrones” Script had “Arya Stark” as the Key to the North.

“Martin has Roose Bolton tell his bastard son: “We have a much better match in mind for you. A match to help House Bolton hold the north. Arya Stark.” - George RR Martin

&D said Sansa’s plot wasn’t that interesting for TV. So they gave her Jeyne’s Poole’s arc to be raped and brutalised. A mess.

After that GRRM decided to stop writing show scripts. 👀 But George looked very happy at this year’s Emmy red carpet and gleeful mentioned that plot points he wrote over 20 years ago will be in S8. D&D both said: the last season of GoT will swing back to George’s original book endgame. At Brazil Comic Con on Thursday, D&D answered Maisie’s question about when they knew how everything would end? They said they were already outlining Season 8 while they were producing Season 3! Holy shit. D&D’s decision to give Sansa more to do (i.e. jeyne poole storyline) was made during S2 BEFORE they knew how everything would end.

In the scripts George RR Martin wrote, he mentioned wanting GoT to go on for 12 or 13 seasons. And with more direwolf scenes!
ohmydays.

More from Vanity Fair: The GoT scripts have been archived by HBO in the Writers Guild of America Library in LA.
https://www.vanityfair.com/hollywood/2018/12/game-of-thrones-george-rr-martin-last-script-the-lion-and-the-rose
All the drama this will cause the fandom. Why Vanity Fair?

blog.name: deliciouslyburningtale
blog.title: If You Desire Fire....
blog.description: Bonnie Bennett stan and Bamon lover. Also Daenerys/Jonerys fan and book!Sansa supporter. An anti-TVD and anti-GoT blog. Multi-fandom and Multi-shipper. Not a spoiler-free blog! Side Blog: ss-alegna.tumblr.com

tags: didn't mean to ramble but I got a lot to say about my otp
body:
@anotherjonsa really shouldn’t be crosstagging, but since they are here in the jonerys tag I’m going to try and debunk each of the main points they brought up. Also be aware that I am mostly using show canon and bits of book info I picked up from other meta/theory writers.  

THE STORY IS ANTI-TARGARYEN Jonerys shippers talk about the Targaryen dynasty like Dany does as if it was ~300 years of absolute peace and prosperity, which is just wrong.

1.) You right, there have been some bad Targaryen rulers and the occasional wars that cropped up within the 300 years of their rule. However, there have been just as many good Targaryen kings as there have been bad ones. The fact that the Targaryens have held power over the Seven Kingdoms for so long goes to show how truly powerful and influential they were; even after the disappearance of dragons they continue to rule for another century or so. While Robert Baratheon could barely keep the realm together after the end of his rebellion; which became more apparent after his death since the Lannisters quickly swept in to take the Iron Throne, and the War of the Five Kings immediately followed.

If anything, the story GRRM is writing isn’t Anti-Targaryen, instead it’s more an anti-war narrative. That’s why he shows how the petty disputes between the great houses negatively affect the economy of Westeros and sometimes focus on the suffering of the common-folk, as all these trivial battles will eventually make it harder for our heroes to come together to fight against the true enemy beyond the wall. George is trying to build a grey world with grey characters, so this idea that Targs are the only house who shouldn’t rule over the Seven Kingdoms, is inherently wrong. Just as there are some good and bad Targs; there are some good and bad Lannisters, Baratheons, Tullys, Martells, and even the Starks are not completely without fault. 

Jaehaerys I made some good changes to Westeros but literally sulked for a year because he couldn’t marry his sister. Alysanne was good but very much overhyped.

And I also find it very amusing that you criticize Jaehaerys and Alysanne as being “overhyped”, but the majority of the J0nsa fandom seemed to be the proponent in comparing them to Jon and Sansa respectively. They insistently made metas and theories revolving around Sansa being Good Queen Alysanne come again, and Jon is the Wise King who will rule by her side.  

The smallfolk dont care (ie. that quote from Arya’s chapter when someone says ‘good king aerys’) you might say, but that’s because they are uneducated. Time and time again GRRM shows how messed up the Targaryens are. Marrying your relative is disgusting, messy, and it shows in all the mad Targaryens.  

Also, maybe…just maybe, the guy who praised Mad King Aerys for being a “good king” might have actually believed he was a decent ruler from his own perspective. Just like how many people seen Tywin Lannister as a “hero” during/after Robert’s Rebellion, even though he allowed one of his knights to rape and kill Elia Martell and the murder of her two innocent children. After all, history is usually written by the winners, hardly is it ever written by the losers. Also, while on the topic of Tywin, you mentioned that marrying your relative is disgusting and messy, but seemed to omit J0nsa from that observation. A good comparison is Tywin’s and Johanna’s relationship, as they were cousins who married and produced three children. You seem to think that centuries of Targ brother-sister incest was what led to their madness, but “Mad Queen” Cersei was a direct product of cousin-cousin incest and her descent into madness seemed to be a parallel to Mad King Aerys’. 

Despite what anyone says, Jon and Sansa being in a romantic relationship is still a form of incest. Even if they do not share as much blood/dna as Jon would with Dany, it doesn’t change the fact that Sansa and Jon both call Ned Stark “father” and refer to each other as sister/brother. Not only do they biologically share a certain amount of dna, but they were raised in a family environment together among other siblings; which makes this incestuous relationship even more bizarre than Jon and Dany (who are two strangers falling in love).   

DAENERYS IS THE MAD QUEEN What qualities make a good ruler? Kindness, patience, thoughtfulness, approachable, grateful, peaceful. Unfortunately for anyone who must suffer under her tyrannical rule, Dany is mad.

2.) I am sick of this Mad!Dany hullabaloo. I understand that burning someone alive is a very horrendous form of death; but that didn’t really stop Stannis from burning people alive at the stakes when they didn’t bend the knee to him, or forsake their religious beliefs. Nor do I hear people call Tyrion “mad” for using really hot and uncontrollable wildfire against Stannis’s fleets during Battle of Blackwater Bay, which was easily set off by one single arrow. And people were fine when Jon Snow used fire against the Wildling invasion on the Wall at Castle Black.

Several people in this series had used fire in battles to win wars, as fire is a very effective weapon to use. So it is mind-boggling when I hear and see these theories about Dany going mad, mostly because she happens to favor the use of her dragons to win battles. Though Dany have consistently shown how kind, patient, thoughtful, approachable, grateful, and peaceful she could and would be throughout the show. It seem like a certain group of people rather focus on what they construed as bad/evil aspects in Daenerys, but also conveniently ignore the good she had done. 

  • Have you forgotten the kindness she had shown when she claimed all the Lhazareen women to keep them from being raped, or when she tried to give water to a crucified male slave with her own hands?
  • Have you forgotten how patient she was when she allowed Tyrion to make his case (aka tell a story) to her when he first came to Meereen, even though he was a Lannister and a son of the man who betrayed her family? 
  • Have you forgotten how thoughtful she was for deciding to chain her two dragons (her children), after a young girl was tragically burned to death by Drogon, in order to keep this incident from happening again? 
  • Have you forgotten how approachable she was for the many slaves who came to call her “Mhysa” after she freed them from slavery, as she went down to meet them despite her advisors warnings against doing so? 
  • Have you forgotten how grateful she was for Jorah’s friendship and continued loyalty, even though he had originally planned on betraying her to Robert Baratheon and then hidden this fact from her years after? 
  • Have you forgotten how much she was willing to achieve peace in Meereen, to the point she had reopen up the fighting pits and entered an arranged marriage with a man who she did not love (and is most likely a hidden enemy) to stop the attacks from the SotH?      

Think of all the people she has murdered, not even letting them die in a dignified way….   

And forgive me if I do not feel much sympathy when Daenerys decide to burn people like the slave masters who had owned living breathing humans as if they were cattle to be bought or sold. Or when she had burned the khals within the temple of the Dosh Khaleen, after they kidnapped her and threatened to rape and abuse her as they pleased. Nor can I muster up much understanding for a certain need to victimize Randyll Tarly, as if this guy didn’t aligned himself with Cersei Lannister (of all people) and commit treason against his liege lady, Olenna Tyrell. And I’m pretty sure Samwell Tarly wouldn’t be so torn up about his father’s death, as his father had regularly emotionally (and possibly physically) abused him, and even subtly threatening to kill him if he didn’t become a member of the Night’s Watch.      

WHY WOULD JON WANT HER? You ask why Jon would want Sansa, well, why would he want Dany??

3.) I’m pretty sure there are a lot of reasons why Jon would want to be with Daenerys Stormborn of House Targaryen; outside of her physical beauty, powerful army, and being a potential ally. Daenerys have just about everything Jon would need to have a chance of defeating the Night King and his army, but she also has the characteristics that he would find most attractive: Lovely, lethal, and lonely. Also, Dany isn’t a typical courteous Westeros lady who sits patiently waiting in a tower needing to be rescued, instead Dany is a fierce warrior queen who does the rescuing.

Her father murdered his innocent grandfather and uncle, wanted to kill his father/uncle Ned, and (as far as he knows) her brother kidnapped his aunt/mother Lyanna. Let’s be honest, it wasn’t technically Dany’s fault but still, it would be a sore point, I think.

I also do not see why Jon will hold the deaths of his grandfather, uncle, and aunt (his mother) Lyanna against Daenerys; when the 1st and 2nd episode of GoT s7 already made it clear that Jon Snow isn’t the type to blame the sins of the father against the children. (Especially since Catelyn ended up blaming Ned’s “sin” onto Jon, even though he had no control over Ned’s choices and didn’t even know who his mother was.)

Also, the Starks might be less forgiving of her father’s burning their family when they discover Dany too is quite happy to burn people alive when it suits her.

And as I brought up in my first point, the Starks aren’t saints either. You like to keep pointing out that Dany burns people alive, but ignore the fact that Bran had on several occasions forcibly skinchanged into a mentally-disabled Hodor and used his body against his will. Arya have mercilessly killed several people in disturbing ways and actually enjoyed committing some of those murders, such as her killing Walder Frey after letting him eat his sons that were baked in a meat pie. Even proper lady Sansa had found satisfaction in watching Ramsey Bolton getting eaten alive by his own hunting dogs. And though I love Sansa Stark, I can’t help but think that she was fairly hypocritical for wanting to throw Alys Karstark and Ned Umber out of their ancestral homes because of their traitorous fathers’ wrongdoings; even though she had been abused in King’s Landings at the hands of Joffery and Cersei, as she too was unjustly blamed for her father’s and Robb’s “traitorous” actions. 

Once again, I hardly hear any of these characters getting the same level of backlash Dany does when they commit these appalling acts, which makes this argument seem very biased. If Jon is going to be horrified by Dany burning her enemies alive, then he should be equally appalled by Stannis (who ended up burning his own daughter, Shireen) and Melisandre, but we already know that Jon was willing to spare Melisandre life regardless of her heinous actions….  

SHE KEPT JON AS PRISONER Dany didn’t let Jon leave Dragonstone when she knew he had to get back to Winterfell as soon as possible, even if she didn’t believe him when it came to the Others….Yet she keeps him there, delaying him further and further.

4.) I cannot deny that Jon Snow remarked that he felt like a prisoner on Dragonstone in the beginning of his stay, I concede with this point. However, this does not deny the fact that Daenerys treated him with respect that most wouldn’t be given if they were truly prisoners. Whereas, Tyrion was once locked up in a sky cell which opened up to the steep drop off a mountain’s cliff, and Jaime was held chained in a small filthy cage and constantly facing threats to his life; Jon was instead given a chamber to sleep in and was honestly treated more like a guest. He never complained about not getting food or water, he never seemed to truly fear for his life around Dany’s men (while without his sword), and he definitely didn’t complain about getting free access to the cave filled with his sought-after dragonglass.

The fact that Daenerys was willing to allow Jon to mine the dragonglass (that he obviously wanted) which is on her land, with some extra help of her Dothraki warriors without any form of payment or favor, just reveals how generous Dany truly is. Also, Daenerys seemed to have allowed Jon to roam Dragonstone without an escort, enough so that he was able to talk to Missandei (Dany’s most trusted advisor and friend) with only Davos as his semi-constant companion.

Manipulating him, even. Until the only way he can get her help when his people will die is to fuck her.

And this spiel about Daenerys “manipulating” Jon Snow needs to end, because she does not need to manipulate him. Dany could have easily taken the North with her three grown dragons, her army of trained Unsullied, and Dothraki horse-riders (i.e. Aegon the Conqueror come again ) if she wanted to, just as she could have easily destroyed Cersei if she had gone through with burning the Red Keep, but she didn’t. Because Daenerys doesn’t want to cause unneeded casualties when she can go the peaceful route, so that is why she demands Jon to bend the knee, but never truly forces him to do so. And the J0nsa fandom is truly confusing me, who is manipulating who; is Jon the political mastermind or is it Daenarys?

Honestly, if anyone was manipulating someone, it was Tyrion-Freaking-Lannister who wrote and sent the letter to Jon and have him come under false presumptions. (It was also Tyrion who thought of the dumb Wight-hunt plan, which nearly caused Jon’s second death. Dany was against it in the beginning, but conceded after Jon stated that he was a king and can make his own choices.) And the thought of Jon having to sexually manipulate any woman to get his way is very disgusting and twisted. I don’t care how much you like or dislike Dany (or any character for the matter), the idea that manipulating someone’s feelings via sex is somehow acceptable because “she wouldn’t help his people otherwise”, is reprehensible. 

Like, really? Go back and re-watch the scene of Daenerys talking to a recovering bare-chested Jon and tell me that she didn’t just swear to fight for the North against the AotD, on her own free-will. After all; she had just recently lost one of her children, saw how many White Walkers were coming, and had seen the threat of the Night King with her very own eyes. Why wouldn’t she want to help Jon Snow fight to save humanity after that? As I had pointed out before, Dany is too compassionate, too thoughtful, and too fearless to allow an undead army to come and destroy what she believe could be her home. And it is because of these attributes that Jon decided to finally bend the knee and proclaimed her as “his queen”.  

Whew! I still have even more to say about why Jonerys is still a viable canon ship, but I just wanted to spend the time to try and give my opinion. Of course, my meta isn’t as great as the ones @oadara or @instantbouquetface-me have written, but I think I was able to express some of my thoughts clearly.

Nor can I muster up much understanding for a certain need to victimize Randyll Tarly, as if this guy didn’t aligned himself with Cersei Lannister (of all people) and commit treason against his liege lady, Olenna Tyrell. And I’m pretty sure Samwell Tarly wouldn’t be so torn up about his father’s death, as his father had regularly emotionally (and possibly physically) abused him, and even subtly threatening to kill him if he didn’t become a member of the Night’s Watch.      

WHY WOULD JON WANT HER? You ask why Jon would want Sansa, well, why would he want Dany??

3.) I’m pretty sure there are a lot of reasons why Jon would want to be with Daenerys Stormborn of House Targaryen; outside of her physical beauty, powerful army, and being a potential ally. Daenerys have just about everything Jon would need to have a chance of defeating the Night King and his army, but she also has the characteristics that he would find most attractive: Lovely, lethal, and lonely. Also, Dany isn’t a typical courteous Westeros lady who sits patiently waiting in a tower needing to be rescued, instead Dany is a fierce warrior queen who does the rescuing.

Her father murdered his innocent grandfather and uncle, wanted to kill his father/uncle Ned, and (as far as he knows) her brother kidnapped his aunt/mother Lyanna. Let’s be honest, it wasn’t technically Dany’s fault but still, it would be a sore point, I think.

I also do not see why Jon will hold the deaths of his grandfather, uncle, and aunt (his mother) Lyanna against Daenerys; when the 1st and 2nd episode of GoT s7 already made it clear that Jon Snow isn’t the type to blame the sins of the father against the children. (Especially since Catelyn ended up blaming Ned’s “sin” onto Jon, even though he had no control over Ned’s choices and didn’t even know who his mother was.)

Also, the Starks might be less forgiving of her father’s burning their family when they discover Dany too is quite happy to burn people alive when it suits her.

And as I brought up in my first point, the Starks aren’t saints either. You like to keep pointing out that Dany burns people alive, but ignore the fact that Bran had on several occasions forcibly skinchanged into a mentally-disabled Hodor and used his body against his will. Arya have mercilessly killed several people in disturbing ways and actually enjoyed committing some of those murders, such as her killing Walder Frey after letting him eat his sons that were baked in a meat pie. Even proper lady Sansa had found satisfaction in watching Ramsey Bolton getting eaten alive by his own hunting dogs. And though I love Sansa Stark, I can’t help but think that she was fairly hypocritical for wanting to throw Alys Karstark and Ned Umber out of their ancestral homes because of their traitorous fathers’ wrongdoings; even though she had been abused in King’s Landings at the hands of Joffery and Cersei, as she too was unjustly blamed for her father’s and Robb’s “traitorous” actions. 

Once again, I hardly hear any of these characters getting the same level of backlash Dany does when they commit these appalling acts, which makes this argument seem very biased. If Jon is going to be horrified by Dany burning her enemies alive, then he should be equally appalled by Stannis (who ended up burning his own daughter, Shireen) and Melisandre, but we already know that Jon was willing to spare Melisandre life regardless of her heinous actions….  

SHE KEPT JON AS PRISONER Dany didn’t let Jon leave Dragonstone when she knew he had to get back to Winterfell as soon as possible, even if she didn’t believe him when it came to the Others….Yet she keeps him there, delaying him further and further.

4.) I cannot deny that Jon Snow remarked that he felt like a prisoner on Dragonstone in the beginning of his stay, I concede with this point. However, this does not deny the fact that Daenerys treated him with respect that most wouldn’t be given if they were truly prisoners. Whereas, Tyrion was once locked up in a sky cell which opened up to the steep drop off a mountain’s cliff, and Jaime was held chained in a small filthy cage and constantly facing threats to his life; Jon was instead given a chamber to sleep in and was honestly treated more like a guest. He never complained about not getting food or water, he never seemed to truly fear for his life around Dany’s men (while without his sword), and he definitely didn’t complain about getting free access to the cave filled with his sought-after dragonglass.

The fact that Daenerys was willing to allow Jon to mine the dragonglass (that he obviously wanted) which is on her land, with some extra help of her Dothraki warriors without any form of payment or favor, just reveals how generous Dany truly is. Also, Daenerys seemed to have allowed Jon to roam Dragonstone without an escort, enough so that he was able to talk to Missandei (Dany’s most trusted advisor and friend) with only Davos as his semi-constant companion.

Manipulating him, even. Until the only way he can get her help when his people will die is to fuck her.

And this spiel about Daenerys “manipulating” Jon Snow needs to end, because she does not need to manipulate him. Dany could have easily taken the North with her three grown dragons, her army of trained Unsullied, and Dothraki horse-riders (i.e. Aegon the Conqueror come again ) if she wanted to, just as she could have easily destroyed Cersei if she had gone through with burning the Red Keep, but she didn’t. Because Daenerys doesn’t want to cause unneeded casualties when she can go the peaceful route, so that is why she demands Jon to bend the knee, but never truly forces him to do so. And the J0nsa fandom is truly confusing me, who is manipulating who; is Jon the political mastermind or is it Daenarys?

Honestly, if anyone was manipulating someone, it was Tyrion-Freaking-Lannister who wrote and sent the letter to Jon and have him come under false presumptions. (It was also Tyrion who thought of the dumb Wight-hunt plan, which nearly caused Jon’s second death. Dany was against it in the beginning, but conceded after Jon stated that he was a king and can make his own choices.) And the thought of Jon having to sexually manipulate any woman to get his way is very disgusting and twisted. I don’t care how much you like or dislike Dany (or any character for the matter), the idea that manipulating someone’s feelings via sex is somehow acceptable because “she wouldn’t help his people otherwise”, is reprehensible. 

Like, really? Go back and re-watch the scene of Daenerys talking to a recovering bare-chested Jon and tell me that she didn’t just swear to fight for the North against the AotD, on her own free-will. After all; she had just recently lost one of her children, saw how many White Walkers were coming, and had seen the threat of the Night King with her very own eyes. Why wouldn’t she want to help Jon Snow fight to save humanity after that? As I had pointed out before, Dany is too compassionate, too thoughtful, and too fearless to allow an undead army to come and destroy what she believe could be her home. And it is because of these attributes that Jon decided to finally bend the knee and proclaimed her as “his queen”.  

Whew! I still have even more to say about why Jonerys is still a viable canon ship, but I just wanted to spend the time to try and give my opinion. Of course, my meta isn’t as great as the ones @oadara or @instantbouquetface-me have written, but I think I was able to express some of my thoughts clearly.

@anotherjonsa really shouldn’t be crosstagging, but since they are here in the jonerys tag I’m going to try and debunk each of the main points they brought up. Also be aware that I am mostly using show canon and bits of book info I picked up from other meta/theory writers.  

THE STORY IS ANTI-TARGARYEN Jonerys shippers talk about the Targaryen dynasty like Dany does as if it was ~300 years of absolute peace and prosperity, which is just wrong.

1.) You right, there have been some bad Targaryen rulers and the occasional wars that cropped up within the 300 years of their rule. However, there have been just as many good Targaryen kings as there have been bad ones. The fact that the Targaryens have held power over the Seven Kingdoms for so long goes to show how truly powerful and influential they were; even after the disappearance of dragons they continue to rule for another century or so. While Robert Baratheon could barely keep the realm together after the end of his rebellion; which became more apparent after his death since the Lannisters quickly swept in to take the Iron Throne, and the War of the Five Kings immediately followed.

If anything, the story GRRM is writing isn’t Anti-Targaryen, instead it’s more an anti-war narrative. That’s why he shows how the petty disputes between the great houses negatively affect the economy of Westeros and sometimes focus on the suffering of the common-folk, as all these trivial battles will eventually make it harder for our heroes to come together to fight against the true enemy beyond the wall. George is trying to build a grey world with grey characters, so this idea that Targs are the only house who shouldn’t rule over the Seven Kingdoms, is inherently wrong. Just as there are some good and bad Targs; there are some good and bad Lannisters, Baratheons, Tullys, Martells, and even the Starks are not completely without fault. 

Jaehaerys I made some good changes to Westeros but literally sulked for a year because he couldn’t marry his sister. Alysanne was good but very much overhyped.

And I also find it very amusing that you criticize Jaehaerys and Alysanne as being “overhyped”, but the majority of the J0nsa fandom seemed to be the proponent in comparing them to Jon and Sansa respectively. They insistently made metas and theories revolving around Sansa being Good Queen Alysanne come again, and Jon is the Wise King who will rule by her side.  

The smallfolk dont care (ie. that quote from Arya’s chapter when someone says ‘good king aerys’) you might say, but that’s because they are uneducated. Time and time again GRRM shows how messed up the Targaryens are. Marrying your relative is disgusting, messy, and it shows in all the mad Targaryens.  

Also, maybe…just maybe, the guy who praised Mad King Aerys for being a “good king” might have actually believed he was a decent ruler from his own perspective. Just like how many people seen Tywin Lannister as a “hero” during/after Robert’s Rebellion, even though he allowed one of his knights to rape and kill Elia Martell and the murder of her two innocent children. A good comparison is Tywin’s and Johanna’s relationship, as they were cousins who married and produced three children. You seem to think that centuries of Targ brother-sister incest was what led to their madness, but “Mad Queen” Cersei was a direct product of cousin-cousin incest and her descent into madness seemed to be a parallel to Mad King Aerys’.

Even if they do not share as much blood/dna as Jon would with Dany, it doesn’t change the fact that Sansa and Jon both call Ned Stark “father” and refer to each other as sister/brother. Not only do they biologically share a certain amount of dna, but they were raised in a family environment together among other siblings; which makes this incestuous relationship even more bizarre than Jon and Dany (who are two strangers falling in love).   

DAENERYS IS THE MAD QUEEN What qualities make a good ruler? Kindness, patience, thoughtfulness, approachable, grateful, peaceful. Unfortunately for anyone who must suffer under her tyrannical rule, Dany is mad.

I understand that burning someone alive is a very horrendous form of death; but that didn’t really stop Stannis from burning people alive at the stakes when they didn’t bend the knee to him, or forsake their religious beliefs. Nor do I hear people call Tyrion “mad” for using really hot and uncontrollable wildfire against Stannis’s fleets during Battle of Blackwater Bay, which was easily set off by one single arrow. And people were fine when Jon Snow used fire against the Wildling invasion on the Wall at Castle Black.

Several people in this series had used fire in battles to win wars, as fire is a very effective weapon to use. So it is mind-boggling when I hear and see these theories about Dany going mad, mostly because she happens to favor the use of her dragons to win battles.   • Have you forgotten the kindness she had shown when she claimed all the Lhazareen women to keep them from being raped, or when she tried to give water to a crucified male slave with her own hands?
  • Have you forgotten how patient she was when she allowed Tyrion to make his case (aka tell a story) to her when he first came to Meereen, even though he was a Lannister and a son of the man who betrayed her family? 
  • Have you forgotten how thoughtful she was for deciding to chain her two dragons (her children), after a young girl was tragically burned to death by Drogon, in order to keep this incident from happening again? 
  • Have you forgotten how approachable she was for the many slaves who came to call her “Mhysa” after she freed them from slavery, as she went down to meet them despite her advisors warnings against doing so? 
  • Have you forgotten how grateful she was for Jorah’s friendship and continued loyalty, even though he had originally planned on betraying her to Robert Baratheon and then hidden this fact from her years after? 
  • Have you forgotten how much she was willing to achieve peace in Meereen, to the point she had reopen up the fighting pits and entered an arranged marriage with a man who she did not love (and is most likely a hidden enemy) to stop the attacks from the SotH?

blog.title: THE LAST OF THE GIANTS
blog.description: Film student | 20 | She/Her | My Ao3 | Fanart | Inbox always open | DO NOT GO GENTLE INTO THAT [LONG] NIGHT | Anti GoT |

summary: Can fire and blood be considered an ‘anti-targ restoration’ book? Fleshing out the bad feudalism system Westeros used for 300...
question: Can fire and blood be considered an ‘anti-targ restoration’ book? Fleshing out the bad feudalism system Westeros used for 300 years before changes come when a dream of spring is here?
answer:
Here is a link that might help you figure it out :) 

No. 

Mind you, it’s greatly about the politics but not entirely about them: I believe Valyrians were destined to bring union to the peoples of the world against winter, and the Targaryens took on that role. I think the incest was to protect the dragon bonds, which is why dragonriders are canonically physically healthy than incestous Targaryens who don’t ride dragons. I think there is a reason why “Valyrian steel kills white walkers” and dragonfire is the ultimate weapon against them and dragonglass “frozen fire” can only be found in the island inhabited by Targaryens. Along the way, they lost their path. Some of the more recent ones like Jaehaerys II and Rhaegar and Aemon, even non-Targaryens like Stannis and Melisandre, might have tried to veer back in track for that role of literal “protectors of the realm”, but they missed the point. (p.s. I’m not very fond of prophetic heroes or heroes that come from a great line of greatness. I much prefer subversive heroes like Rey who come from nothing, but the Targaryens are still very interesting.) 

“Fleshing out bad feudalism” is pretty broad accusation for decades worth of rulers. The Targaryens built upon the roots that the Andals, the Rhoynar and the First Men planted. They did not bring over a radical change that forced the people of Westeros to adapt to them, but rather they brought on a radical change that made the people of Westeros adapt to each other. 

Aegon united the realm. Jaehaerys established it. Alysanne improved it. But the Targaryens are not gods, despite their power, they are men. They are human. Along the line, they lost sight of what was important and only came to care too much about the throne. It follows through the themes of ASOIAF, that humanity must unite and prioritize itself to save each other. 

The Targaryens are not GRRM’s pure sacred babies just as the Starks aren’t pure sacred babies, but if you’ve read anything about his relation to Targaryens, the tales of Dunk and Egg Aegon the Unlikely, Maester’s Aemon’s wisdom, Jon’s courage, and Dany’s plight for freedom, you should know by now that George is not anti-Targaryen.

Aegon united the realm. Jaehaerys established it. Alysanne improved it. But the Targaryens are not gods, despite their power, they are men. They are human. Along the line, they lost sight of what was important and only came to care too much about the throne. It follows through the themes of ASOIAF, that humanity must unite and prioritize itself to save each other. 

The Targaryens are not GRRM’s pure sacred babies just as the Starks aren’t pure sacred babies, but if you’ve read anything about his relation to Targaryens, the tales of Dunk and Egg Aegon the Unlikely, Maester’s Aemon’s wisdom, Jon’s courage, and Dany’s plight for freedom, you should know by now that George is not anti-Targaryen.

summary: So, speaking of George R. R. Martin’s original notes to his publisher, I have to say the first moment I began to suspect not...
caption:
So, speaking of George R. R. Martin’s original notes to his publisher, I have to say the first moment I began to suspect not only that the notes were not only still relevant in many ways, but that the tv series would likely get as close as it possibly could to whatever ending Martin was working towards, and that the show would move all the characters into place to get to that ending, was this recapt trailer that HBO posted before Season 7 started, back in 2017.

For me, this trailer pretty much confirmed the “five core characters” Martin mentioned in his notes as still being the core five characters for the story. Because at certain points in the trailer, each of those five characters are specifically highlighted, signaling the five of them out among all the other characters who are in the trailer, as if saying “Hey! Make sure you pay specific attention to these people!”  

Tyrion: 1:10

Daenerys: 1:45  

Jon: 2:40

Bran: 3:38

Arya: 4:03

And now, recently, we’ve just had the #ForTheThrone stills and promos a few weeks ago. And, once again, all five of these characters each specifically got one. In fact, the only other characters to get one of these promos, who are still alive, are Cersei and the Night King (as much as you can call a White Walker “alive” at any rate). And those two are clearly the two final antagonists. 

So while I think many things in those publisher notes got changed or moved or altered completely, I still think it hold a lot of still-relevant information as well. Maybe even more than anyone suspects.
